data.title: Gold and US assets will be the "winners" after the attack on Iran.
data.description: What is certain is that the United States and Israel are seeking a complete regime change in Iran. According to the Wall Street Journal, Israel claims that Saturday's joint attack killed Iran's Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Other Iranian leaders remain primary targets. It is too early to draw conclusions, but the intensity of this full-scale offensive suggests that the regional conflict may escalate further before it improves. While energy markets and the global economy will be widely impacted, investors should carefully assess the potential consequences of the conflict before rushing to buy on dips. Financial markets should prioritize risk aversion until the losses can be quantified and reasonably assessed. The US leadership must have realized that Iran's participation in the Geneva talks over its nuclear capabilities over the past two weeks has been merely a delaying tactic. Iranian negotiators have failed to make even the smallest concessions to their US counterparts—namely, the permanent and complete dismantling of uranium enrichment facilities, which could have averted war. The two sides were originally scheduled to continue negotiations at the International Atomic Energy Agency meeting in Vienna next week, but the US clearly felt there was no reason to wait a few more days, only to find out that Iran had no intention of making any substantial concessions. Therefore, the US and Israel seized the last remaining opportunity for a surprise attack after a massive military buildup in the region over the past few weeks, striking Iranian missile and drone launch sites, military command facilities, and targets in the capital. Now, the fog of war has enveloped the region. At first glance, the infrastructure damage appears limited—the US has not destroyed Iran's nuclear capabilities or key oil export terminals in the region—but this appearance may be misleading. In the coming days and possibly weeks, the US attacks and Iranian retaliation are likely to escalate. The Iranian regime faces collapse and has no way out. In fact, it now has ample motivation to attack regional energy infrastructure, thereby triggering a global economic shock. This could weaken American public support for the war and the determination of US leaders to push the war to the end until regime change. This could also fuel global opposition to the US and Israel, which would benefit the Iranian regime should it survive. Even if initial actual damage appears limited, investors should prepare for the inevitable disruption of regional energy supplies. The Iranian leadership has signaled its intention to close the crucial Strait of Hormuz—through which approximately 20% of the world's oil and 15% of its liquefied natural gas are transported. Shipping through the strait is already spontaneously decreasing. If the attack successfully affects ships, oil wells, pipelines, or ports, the disruption will no longer be voluntary or temporary. The direct market impact will be: a decline in global stock markets and a strengthening of global safe-haven assets. Gold will continue its bull market. If an actual disruption to oil supply means a non-speculative rise in oil prices, thus suppressing consumer demand, then US Treasury bonds will particularly benefit. If global economic growth slows due to this turmoil, global stock markets are likely to decline, but US stocks should perform relatively better. Over the past year, we've seen a trend of funds flowing into European, Japanese, and Chinese stock markets. This trend will be difficult to sustain if the profits and profit margins of companies in these energy-import-dependent manufacturing economies suffer unexpected shocks. Other stock markets in the Americas will also benefit relatively, as they can rely on local oil supplies and are far from conflict zones. Investors should only buy global stocks on dips and sell oil on rallies when it is clear that war damage will not affect energy supplies. Until then, they should not do so.

Today, a chilling stillness hangs over Shemiran, north of Tehran. For Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, this stillness usually signifies security, but on this day, it is a prelude to death. This raid, codenamed "Operation Epic Fury," was not a traditional large-scale bombing, but a "surgical operation" woven from low-level code, real-time remote sensing algorithms, and distributed computing power. Following the attack, Trump confirmed Khamenei's death on social media. The significance of this operation lies in the fact that it is the first high-level decapitation strike in human history where artificial intelligence (AI) has completely dominated the "kill chain." In his command post deep underground in Tehran, Khamenei may have thought he had evaded satellites, but he didn't realize he was facing not a single weapon, but a global surveillance and strike network comprised of Palantir, Anduril, and the top-tier large language model (Claude). This network no longer relies on expensive traditional platforms, but on "software-defined weapons." The Wall Street Journal reports that in this war, AI is no longer an auxiliary tool; it has become the true decision-maker, tracker, and executor.

Silicon Valley's "War Operating System": Palantir

Behind decapitation strikes, Palantir's technology platform plays the role of the "battlefield brain." Founded by Peter Thiel, the company's core mission has always been to break down data silos between intelligence agencies.

Palantir's most powerful weapons are its Artificial Intelligence Platform (AIP) and its flagship product, Gotham 5. In traditional command systems, intelligence analysts need to manually compare satellite imagery, communications interception records, and open-source social media data. But in Operation Epic Wrath, Palantir's Ontology technology transformed this chaotic data into intuitive, real-world objects. The so-called "ontology" maps complex enterprise or battlefield data into easily understood entities, such as "personnel," "locations," or "launchpads." By integrating data from ERP systems, sensors, satellites, and network monitoring into a "Common Operating Picture" (COP), commanders are no longer faced with dry reports, but with a real-time digital twin of the battlefield.

This wartime capability reduced system updates that would normally take months to hours.

To understand this operation, one must first understand how the US military broke through Iran's impenetrable electromagnetic blockade. Before the operation began, Tehran cut off terrestrial internet and mobile communications throughout the country, attempting to render US sensors "blind." This is no longer the semi-civilian Starlink terminals used on the Ukrainian battlefield. Starshield consists of approximately 480 dedicated hardened satellites and integrates the highest security encryption protocol at the NSA level. In the operational logs of the U.S. Central Command (CENTCOM), these satellites were figuratively called "digital oxygen": when the Iranian Revolutionary Guard attempted to sever frontline communications using the Russian-made Kalinka jamming system, StarShield established a perpetually connected aerial grid in orbit via laser inter-satellite links reaching speeds of up to 200 Gbps. Most formidable was the compact terminal known as UAT-222. Measuring only two feet square, it could be carried by a single special forces soldier. When this small cube was activated in a bunker near the Tehran residence, petabytes of high-resolution images and electromagnetic signals that would normally take hours to transmit were transmitted within seconds, penetrating the jamming smoke and flowing directly into Palantir's analysis engine.

Claude: A Game About the Soul of AI

However, in the process of AI killing Khamenei, a fierce conflict about AI ethics erupted in the United States. The focus of the conflict was Claude, the top-tier large-scale model developed by Anthropic.

As the only cutting-edge large-scale model authorized by the Pentagon to operate on a highly classified, physically isolated network, Claude was once the most relied-upon tool for US military intelligence analysts. Its "Claude Gov" version excelled at processing massive amounts of intercepted Persian classified documents. Claude's role in operations was not to directly control weapons, but rather to process massive amounts of unstructured warfare data. According to declassified documents, the US military first used Claude on a large scale for "intelligence synthesis" in its operation against Venezuelan leader Maduro in early 2026. Claude can rapidly read thousands of hours of intercepted Persian communications, identify cracks in the command chain within the Iranian Revolutionary Guard, and generate dozens of dynamic game-theoretic strike scenario simulations for commanders. Analysts no longer need to write lengthy briefings; they can simply ask, as easily as ordering food: "If we were to electronically suppress Tehran at this moment, and simultaneously launch an air strike, what would be Khamenei's most likely escape route?" Claude will then provide an optimized interception probability chart based on its massive military theoretical training and real-time intelligence feed. However, according to an exclusive report by The Wall Street Journal in February 2026, an open hostility erupted between the Trump administration and Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered Anthropic to remove all of Claude's guardrails so that it could be directly integrated into the fully automated lethal weapon system. Instead, OpenAI and Elon Musk's xAI were put at the heart of the U.S. military's most secretive missions because of its promise of providing computing power "unbound by political correctness." Ironically, in the operation against Khamenei, the Claude model running on the Palantir platform still played a crucial supporting role—although it refused to pull the trigger directly, it cleared the fog of intelligence for the final strike by processing previous covert operations against Venezuelan President Maduro and petabytes of data intercepted in Tehran. "Where's Dad?": Algorithms Track Every Person. If Palantir and Claude provided strategic-level intelligence, then the three AI systems developed by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) reveal the most chilling logic at the tactical level. These three systems are collectively known as the "mass assassination factory." In operations against Tehran, the US military drew upon algorithms honed by the IDF in combat in Gaza.

  • “The Gospel”: An AI system specifically designed to recommend targets for buildings. It can generate strike lists at a rate of 100 per day, while humans could only generate 50 per year in the past.

  • “Lavender”: Scores millions of people and automatically tags suspected militants by analyzing social networks, movement patterns, and call logs. At its peak, it tagged 37,000 targets.24 The most controversial part lies in the role of humans. According to The Guardian, after these AI systems recommend targets, human commanders often spend only "20 seconds" reviewing them. These 20 seconds are merely enough to confirm whether the target is male. Even more brutal is a system called "Where's Daddy?". Instead of tracking aircraft like traditional radar, it tracks the connection between targets and their home residences. The system automatically monitors when tagged individuals enter their homes. Commanders believe that attacking these individuals when they are home with their families is easier than attacking military outposts, even though it means that the entire building's civilian population could become "collateral damage." In the process of Khamenei's assassination, this logic was elevated to the level of national leaders. The algorithm no longer searched for Khamenei's luxurious car, but rather for every subtle feature of him. Anduril and Shield AI: Software-Defined Air Superiority To execute the final strike, the US military no longer repeatedly deployed expensive stealth aircraft, but instead used Cooperative Combat Aircraft (CCA) defined by new military industries such as Anduril and Shield AI. A key technological highlight of this operation was the drone swarm's ability to autonomously adjust its formation based on real-time threat perception after entering Tehran's airspace. When Iranian air defense radar locked onto one of the drones, the entire swarm shared this threat through the Lattice software system and automatically dispatched a group of drones for electronic guidance and anti-radiation strikes. This "software-driven" warfare makes traditional, hardware-centric defense systems appear cumbersome and outdated when faced with algorithmic iterations. Shield AI is a company focused on developing what it calls "the world's best AI pilot"—Hivemind. This software allows unmanned systems to perform complex tasks even when completely without GPS, satellite communications, and human operators. The core technology of Hivemind is EdgeOS, a middleware environment specifically designed for high-performance real-time robotics. Its core features include:

    Aerial Brain Swap: The Power of the A-GRA Architecture

    In February 2026, Anduril demonstrated an experiment that shocked the military: its YFQ-44A drone successfully switched between two completely different AI systems during flight. The first half of the flight was controlled by Shield AI's "Hivemind" software, which allowed the drone to autonomously avoid obstacles and form formations like a bird; the second half seamlessly switched to Anduril's "Lattice" system to perform the final target lock.

    This "aerial brain swap" relies on a modular standard known as the "Government Reference Autonomous Architecture" (A-GRA). This means that if the enemy develops electronic jamming against a certain AI, the drone can instantly download and run another algorithm, just like updating an app on a mobile phone. EagleEye Headset: The Soldier's "Digital Teammate" In ground operations, US special forces soldiers wear the EagleEye mixed reality headset, jointly developed by Anduriel and Meta (formerly Facebook). This headset is no longer a bulky bulletproof helmet, but a holographic display system integrating all data from the Lattice network. Soldiers can directly see the enemy's skeletal posture, the outline of obscured targets, and even see real-time images transmitted back by aerial drones directly from the headset. data.title: Partnering with Republic MSX aims to make SpaceX shareholders accessible to the general public.
data.description:
Have you ever considered becoming a shareholder before SpaceX lands on the moon or before ByteDance rings its IPO? In traditional financial terms, this opportunity is called "Pre-IPO" private equity investment. It typically occurs in the final stretch before unicorns like SpaceX and ByteDance officially go public. At this point, the business model is extremely mature, and the risk is far lower than early-stage venture capital. However, the return on investment after the company goes public is still astonishing—at least doubled, and sometimes several times or even dozens of times higher. However, for a long time, this lucrative opportunity has been exclusively enjoyed by private equity (PE) and venture capital (VC). Ordinary retail investors have been kept outside the highly closed walls, mostly waiting to buy shares in the secondary market after the company goes public. Ultimately, the opportunity of "Pre-IPO" has long been out of reach for most people. Now, MSX has decided to cross this high wall through a combination of tokenization and a Wall Street compliance platform. I. The Trillion-Dollar Cake Within the Walls: Visible, But Intangible Data shows that the size of the "Pre-IPO" market has far exceeded expectations. The "2025 Global Unicorn 500 Report" shows that the total valuation of the 2025 Global Unicorn 500 companies reached 39.14 trillion yuan, a year-on-year increase of 30.71%, far exceeding the GDP of Germany, the world's third-largest economy. The average valuation also rose from 59.883 billion yuan to 78.276 billion yuan, a year-on-year increase of 30.71%. In his article, "Why Private Equity Wins: Reflecting on a Quarter-Century of Outperformance," Dawson Managing Partner Yann Robard also points out that the value created by the private equity market over the past 25 years is about three times that of the stock market during the same period. In other words, the stage that truly generates excess returns often occurs before an IPO. Taking SpaceX, currently the world's number one unicorn, as an example, a unique analysis by MSX reveals that its primary market valuation was only $180 billion in 2024, subsequently climbing steeply. By early 2026, after completing the share swap integration with xAI, its private valuation had reached $1.25 trillion, a six-fold increase in just two years. The price of private equity transfers of SpaceX in the off-market also surged from about $56 per share in October 2021 to about $527 per share in February 2026, almost nine times in four years. It can be said that equity in unlisted unicorn companies has always been a super alpha in global asset allocation, a fact everyone is well aware of. However, in this trillion-dollar sector with rapidly growing valuations, the entry rules are extremely unequal: ● The capital threshold often starts at "millions": Entry fees of hundreds of thousands or even millions of dollars directly deter 99.9% of individual investors; ● The "opportunity cost" of liquidity: Once invested, funds are often locked up for 5-10 years, making it difficult to realize profits; ● Extremely Unfair Allocation: For highly sought-after assets like OpenAI, SpaceX, and ByteDance, where buyers line up in droves, quotas are perpetually limited to a small circle of top-tier private equity and venture capital firms. In other words, this is a trillion-dollar market with potentially high returns, yet it has long been open only to institutional investors and ultra-high-net-worth individuals. This is why, in June 2025, when online brokerage giant Robinhood offered European users trading OpenAI and SpaceX "stock tokens," the market paid close attention, viewing it as the first large-scale trial of private equity tokenization by a traditional online brokerage. Because it sent an important signal: using RWA tokenization to dismantle the barriers of the primary market, mapping real equity to on-chain divisible tokens, could redefine limitations on entry barriers, liquidity constraints, and exit efficiency. II. How Will MSX Break Down the Barriers of "Pre-IPO" in Partnership with Republic? Today, MSX officially took over the baton of "investment equality." We have entered into a strategic partnership with Republic, a US-compliant asset tokenization platform, and will soon launch a Pre-IPO zone, providing eligible platform users with tokenized private equity from top global unicorns such as SpaceX and ByteDance. The initial allocation exceeds ten million US dollars, covering more than 10 top global unicorns. Details such as the specific list of targets and the amount released will be announced upon the official launch. However, facing this kind of "Pre-IPO" equity tokenization, your first reaction might be: Is it safe? Is it legal? Is it just a "virtual mapping"? Here, it's necessary to first provide some background information on Republic's project. As a compliant private securities platform operating under the supervision of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), Republic has long provided global investors with access to private equity financing. It is committed to helping individual and institutional investors participate in private markets and alternative assets that were previously only open to a small number of professional investors. Its private assets are held through regulated third-party custodians (such as licensed institutions like BitGo Trust Company). It's worth noting that Republic is also the core service provider behind Robinhood's launch of unlisted unicorn stock tokens in Europe.

This means that MSX's Pre-IPO zone is a structural innovation built on a mature compliance framework. You will enjoy services at the same level as the world's top brokerages: all unicorn equity assets are connected through the same compliance channels as Robinhood, the existing shares behind the mapped tokens are real, and they are held in custody by a regulated third party, with a legal and asset support foundation. Ultimately, when tokenization technology meets compliant private equity platforms regulated by the US SEC, the equity of unlisted giants will no longer be the exclusive domain of top venture capitalists. Third, what does this mean for ordinary users? We also firmly believe that the Pre-IPO products launched this time will bring structural changes to ordinary users in three dimensions. First, it "equalizes" the entry threshold, bidding farewell to entry tickets that often cost millions of dollars. As mentioned above, the starting price in the traditional private equity market is usually hundreds of thousands or even millions of dollars, while tokenization can fragment the previously unattainable unicorn stocks, allowing eligible ordinary users on the Maitong MSX platform to sit at the same table as top venture capitalists with a very low threshold and equally share the future growth premium of SpaceX or ByteDance in the primary and secondary markets. Secondly, it's about "source-leveling" valuation advantages, avoiding the emotional tax of the secondary market. It's well known that the surge on the first day or in the early stages of an IPO is often accompanied by a huge emotional bubble, and ordinary retail investors often enter at high prices. Participating in the pre-IPO stage means capturing the closest possible valuation range. In short, you can finally position yourself at a low valuation stage before the company goes public, instead of becoming a bagholder in the post-IPO frenzy. Finally, it's about "restructuring" the liquidity structure, breaking the illusion of N-year lock-up periods. The most troublesome aspect of traditional private equity investment is the 5-10 year exit lock-up period. To address this pain point, Maitong MSX plans to be the first to launch high-quality pre-IPO targets with short-term redemption mechanisms, and will continue to explore more technical paths to improve asset liquidity, potentially completely reconstructing the exit logic of the primary market. In conclusion, the launch of the "Pre-IPO" zone marks a significant step forward for MSX's US stock tokenization strategy, expanding from "secondary market asset trading" to "primary market share distribution." Amid the global trend of asset tokenization, Pre-IPO tokenization has become a widely discussed key area for the next stage of industry discussion. As one of the earliest trading platforms globally to deeply cultivate US stock tokenization, MSX has consistently focused on one thing: enabling ordinary people to share in the growth dividends of the most scarce high-quality assets of this era, from breaking down barriers to US stock trading to dismantling the walls of private equity. Just as five years ago, ordinary people couldn't imagine instantly buying and selling US stocks through an on-chain wallet; before today, you might have similarly found it difficult to imagine becoming a "shareholder" of SpaceX or ByteDance with extremely low barriers to entry. In 2026, we hope to work with everyone to slowly push open that once tightly closed iron gate.

data.description:
Author: a16z New Media; Translator: Deep Tide TechFlow

This week's a16z chart report covers four topics, each worthy of a separate article: the Jevons effect triggered by declining AI costs, the true scale of tech giants' capital expenditures, Kalshi's prediction market is beating professional forecasting agencies, and the widespread postponement of life milestones for Americans aged 30. The data sources are solid, and the perspective is calm and restrained, making it a high-quality reference for understanding the intersection of current technological and macroeconomic trends.

DExit… Is it a real trend or an illusion?

... Delaware remains the top choice for business registration in the United States, but this position is quietly shifting: According to Ramp data, Delaware's share of new company registrations has been declining since 2023, with a drop of approximately 10% in the third quarter of 2025. History doesn't simply repeat itself, but it often rhymes…maybe. Delaware wasn't always a haven for business registration. About a century ago, Delaware replaced New Jersey—the former "mother of trusts"—as the top choice for business registration. New Jersey lost its edge because then-Governor Woodrow Wilson's attempts to curb "corporate abuses" significantly worsened the state's business environment. Delaware's corporate law, modeled after pre-Wilson New Jersey law, naturally welcomed departing companies and, together with the Delaware Court of Chancery, spent nearly 100 years building a reputation as a mature and impartial forum for resolving disputes between corporations and investors. However, what took a century to build began to crumble in just a few years. Right or wrong, the Delaware Court of Chancery has adopted a more lenient stance in shareholder litigation in recent years (especially in several high-profile cases, including but not limited to Tesla), and companies have begun to genuinely relocate their places of registration. Goodnight, and best of luck, Delaware. This is at least the mainstream narrative, but other data suggests a more complex picture. First, even the founding myth of Delaware itself is not entirely accurate. It wasn't until the 1980s (about 60 years after Governor Wilson took office) that Delaware truly surpassed New Jersey to become the state with the most registered businesses in the United States: New Jersey's reign lasted much longer than the mainstream narrative suggests. The catalyst for Delaware's eventual overtaking was likely the passage of a series of laws related to director responsibilities, which made it particularly attractive to publicly traded companies, coupled with the self-reinforcing network effect that created its own momentum. Secondly, regardless of what's happening with high-profile publicly traded companies (and the companies in the Ramp data), Delaware as a whole still looks to be performing well, or even better: According to data released by the Harvard Law School Corporate Governance Forum, Delaware's share of the total number of businesses in the U.S. actually increased significantly from the end of 2024 to 2025. In fact, if you're looking for a clear "DExit" case, it's probably this one, and it has nothing to do with Tesla, but rather involves a specific company structure: Wyoming LLCs began to grow rapidly around 2015. Why? This is likely related to specific asset protection and privacy provisions in Wyoming LLC law, which the state itself promotes as a "cowboy cocktail." In short, the point here isn't that DExit isn't happening (because at least some data suggests it is—even if it's just a few high-profile companies moving out, it's significant), but the reality is certainly more complex than the mainstream narrative portrays. The reality is that Delaware still enjoys the advantage of being the default option, not to mention all the network effects tied to it, which are difficult to shake. We previously published an earlier version of this chart, but as more data has been added, the results have become increasingly striking. Token costs are decreasing, while token consumption is increasing: Since the beginning of this year, the price of paid tokens has dropped from approximately 90 cents per million tokens to 50 cents, while the number of tokens processed has almost doubled, from approximately 6,000 to 12,000. This is a classic Jevons effect. The cheaper AI becomes, the more AI we use. This is encouraging. Remember when someone said that once newer and better GPUs are released, older GPUs become unwanted? This doesn't seem to be the case: According to Silicon Data, rental prices for NVIDIA H100 and A100 have both increased this year. The market shows no signs of oversupply of computing power; in fact, it seems that even the surface of existing demand hasn't been reached. This comparison isn't a perfect analogy, but if history can provide a reference, it may still take some time before we truly understand what an "AI-driven" economy looks like: From Faraday and Henry's initial discussions of electricity to the real explosion of industrial productivity in the first half of the 20th century, approximately 100 years passed. While the technological iteration cycle has indeed accelerated since the 1820s, the variables involved in a platform-level shift remain extremely numerous. Roy Amara famously said, "We always overestimate what will happen in the next two years and underestimate what will happen in the next ten years." Capital expenditure, viewed on a coordinate axis, reveals this set of timeless data: AI capital expenditure is massive. Please see the following comparison: AI capital expenditures in 2026 are projected to be close to the total net new loans issued by U.S. banks in 2025: Capital expenditures are approximately 33% higher than total U.S. corporate income tax revenue and about three times the total tariffs: Capital expenditures are approximately six times the total military budget of any non-U.S. G7 member country: So, yes, capital expenditures are indeed very large. Kalshi enters the field of macro forecasting. Federal Reserve researchers believe their market forecasting is quite good. At least on one metric, Kalshi's forecasts of the federal funds rate have outperformed professional forecasting agencies: For the federal funds rate forecast 150 days later (i.e., after three FOMC meetings), Kalshi's mean absolute error is very close to that of professional forecasting agencies. However, unlike surveys that only provide modal path snapshots every six weeks, Kalshi provides a continuously updated complete probability distribution… We found that Kalshi's median and mode forecasts have a perfect record of accuracy the day before the FOMC meeting, which is a statistically significant improvement compared to federal funds futures forecasts. In other words, while all forecasters start at roughly the same level, Kalshi's "continuously updated" predictions optimize over time, ultimately achieving a "perfect prediction record" the day before the official interest rate announcement. Furthermore, Kalshi outperforms predictions in the futures market. Kalshi's advantages extend beyond the federal funds rate. As Federal Reserve researchers have pointed out, since there are no other options markets for macroeconomic indicators such as inflation, growth, and unemployment, Kalshi is the only place that can provide a "high-frequency, continuously updated, and probability-rich benchmark" to reflect the "public's" judgment on the direction of these economic indicators. This sounds quite important. The Delay of Adulthood This is a thought-provoking chart, with (a few) comments: The percentage of people in their 30s who achieve major life milestones has been declining quite steeply since at least the 1980s. Fewer and fewer people in their 30s are: living independently; having been married; living with children; or owning their own home. The only exception is college enrollment—the proportion of 30-year-olds with a bachelor's degree has nearly doubled since 1995. So, is going to college worth it? A milestone? More like a millstone grinding your neck, right? Perhaps it is, perhaps it isn't, but a sense of "buyer's regret" seems to be pervasive.

Hello everyone, I'm Chen Tianyuzhou. Today we're going to analyze a letter—Stripe's 2025 Annual Letter. Why analyze it? Because this letter reveals many aspects of the future we haven't seen before, based on Stripe's $1.9 trillion transaction volume! If you're not in the industry, you might not be familiar with Stripe. Simply put, Stripe is a global payment aggregator, similar to Adyen, Pingpong, and Airwallex. This letter, less than 3,000 words long, is packed with information. It's not just the company's year-end summary, but also a deep analysis and forecast of the impact of payments on the entire globalized economic activity. In 2025, Stripe's total transaction volume reached $1.9 trillion. What does this mean? A year-on-year increase of 34%, accounting for approximately 1.6% of global GDP. In other words, for every 100 dollars of wealth produced on Earth, 1.6 dollars goes through Stripe's channels. This figure reached 1.4 trillion dollars in 2024, a staggering increase of 500 billion US dollars in just one year. After reading this letter, I have only one feeling: The old world we know is collapsing and being reconstructed at an unbelievable speed. In this article, I've tried to break down the key points of Stripe's annual letter in my own words, though some parts have been directly translated to maintain the original flavor. The amount of information is indeed vast, but every point is worth pondering. If you are starting a business or in the payments industry, I suggest you read this several times. Every trend here is impacting your future survival. The letter begins by introducing a very core concept—"sorting machine." They say that the market economy is essentially a giant algorithmic machine. Its role is not to make everyone rich, but rather to ruthlessly filter out profits, capital, and talent, and redistribute them to the most productive companies. Previously, this machine operated slowly, and everyone had enough to eat. But now, AI has added an overclocking engine to this machine. Looking at the data: The top third of the most profitable listed companies in the United States account for two-thirds of the entire stock market's market capitalization. This is the highest proportion since data became available in 1963. The top 10% of companies in the S&P 500 contributed 59% of the profits. And this isn't a valuation bubble; it's a genuine concentration of profits. This differentiation isn't just between large and small companies, but also a life-or-death struggle within the industry. The letter gave several examples: Retail Industry: Offline brick-and-mortar sales have only grown by 5% in the past three years, while e-commerce has grown by 30% during the same period. Airline Industry: The three major US airlines—American Airlines, Delta, and United—have seen their market share and profits increase over the past decade. However, by 2025, Delta and United will have captured almost all of the US airline industry's profits. Other airlines will essentially be lagging behind. Healthcare: Hospitals and insurance companies have seen their profit share shrink significantly since 2019, but the healthcare technology sector is projected to exceed $110 billion in EBITDA by 2029. Money is flowing from traditional players to new players. This is the terrifying aspect of "healthcare": Previously it was big fish eat small fish; now it's fast fish eat slow fish, and it's AI-powered fast fish eating slow, clumsy fish. More macro-level data shows that demand for software, computers, and data centers will drive nearly half of the US GDP growth by 2025. And this proportion will soon become the majority. What does this mean? Previously, we said software was eating the world; now, computing power is driving growth. Industries that haven't capitalized on computing power and software are being relentlessly left behind by this machine. AI-Driven Startup Explosion

What has Stripe observed?

In 2025, the number of new companies joining Stripe reached a record high, with 57% coming from outside the United States.

Moreover, these new companies are growing at an absurdly high rate,50% faster than the batch in 2024. Even more astonishingly, companies that achieved annual revenue of $10 million within three months doubled their initial investment. However, AI companies consider this normal practice. Why? Because code commits on GitHub increased by 41%. Previously, annual increases were only 10%-12%, but by 2025, this figure has skyrocketed to 41%. The number of iOS app releases increased by 60% year-over-year in December 2025. Previously, developing an app required a team of over ten people working on it for six months. Now, a programmer and a few AI agents can write some code over the weekend, and the product can be launched and generating revenue the following Monday. Stripe itself has also jumped on this bandwagon. They created something called "claimable sandboxes," allowing you to launch your Stripe account directly from AI programming tools like Manus, Replit, and Vercel. Finished your beta version and want to launch it? With a single click, a sandbox becomes a live account instantly, without any configuration changes. Currently, over 100,000 sandboxes have been created this way. And then there's Stripe Atlas—the world's simplest company registration tool—which saw a 41% increase in company registrations last year. Moreover, these new companies are monetizing much faster: in 2025, 20% of Atlas startups received their first payment from a customer within 30 days, compared to only 8% in 2020. Faced with these figures, we are forced to ask: Is 2025 an anomaly, or the beginning of a new normal? Stripe's assessment is: The acceleration in 2025 marks the beginning of a major inflection point in entrepreneurship and creativity driven by the large language model. This "machine" is accelerating; if you don't break into the top 10%, what awaits you may not be a slow decline, but rather an instantaneous collapse. Globalization is dead, global localization is new. One particularly interesting point in the letter is that "globalization has become the default state." Previously, Chinese business owners had a relatively fixed approach when venturing overseas: first establish a presence domestically, then send people to Southeast Asia or the US to test the waters, and finally consider expanding into Europe. Coca-Cola took 20 years to bottle its first bottle of soda in Cuba. McDonald's and Starbucks took 27 and 16 years respectively to open their first stores in Canada. After the advent of the internet, free services began to be released globally simultaneously, but there was still a delay in the availability of monetization tools. When Facebook opened to the public in 2006, anyone could register an account, but wanting to run ads? Not so easy. By 2009, the company had already been around for 5 years. Google launched its global search in 1998, but didn't receive its first pound advertising payment in the UK until 2002. This strategy failed. What are AI products like now? OpenAI's ChatGPT, Anthropic's Claude, Replit, Cursor, and Midjourney are all launched simultaneously globally, covering all markets in a second. Every AI product we've heard of is incredibly popular in every country we know of. Stripe's data reveals a very unusual phenomenon: For companies whose main revenue comes from overseas, 30% of their revenue comes neither from their home country nor from the top ten economies like the US, China, Japan, and Germany, but from transparent countries that are rarely seen in the news. What does this mean? It means that demand is dispersed, but the tools are unified. Previously, if you wanted to collect money from the Kenyan people, you had to open a branch office in Kenya and negotiate with local banks to connect to M-Pesa. Now? Stripe goes all in, integrating over 120 payment methods for you—all you need to do is click a button in the backend. For example, Gamma, a California-based AI platform with 70 million users for presentations, saw its Indian revenue surge by 22% that month when it integrated with Stripe and enabled UPI payments in India. This is the benefit of next-generation infrastructure: your product can be in San Francisco, but your money can instantly flow into the pocket of a breakfast stall owner in Mumbai. Ironically, the most geographically limited sector isn't traditional industries, but rather fintech companies themselves: Chime, after 12 years, is still stuck in the US. Want to open a Chime account? Forget about it if you're outside the US. Nubank, founded in 2013, served only Brazil for the first six years, and only added two more countries in the next six. Even Stripe itself, with its Issues product launched seven years ago, only covers 22 countries—faster than most, but still not fast enough. But this is also changing. The new generation of fintech players—Sling Money, DolarApp, Felix, and KAST—are building global financial applications from day one. Stripe also launched its first inherently global product, Financial Accounts, last year, which businesses can use to hold, send, and receive funds. On its first day, it covered more than 100 countries. Why can they do this? Because of stablecoins. Their borderless nature allows fintech to build a complete infrastructure. Born global, this is truly possible for the first time. The crypto winter, the stablecoin summer. 2025 may be a crypto winter, but it will definitely be the summer of stablecoins. For the past decade, stablecoin trading volume has fluctuated with cryptocurrency asset prices. But in 2025, this correlation broke. That year, Bitcoin prices plummeted, dropping 50% from their peak. Logically, shouldn't the crypto world be entering another "winter is coming" phase? But strangely, stablecoin payment volume has doubled, reaching $400 billion. And it's estimated that 60% of that is B2B payments. This is the key quote from the letter: "Crypto Winter, but Stablecoin Summer." Previously, people traded cryptocurrencies to get rich, but now they use stablecoins to save money and make quick money. Stripe's acquisition of Bridge, a stablecoin orchestration platform, saw its trading volume increase more than fourfold. The path for entrepreneurs has changed: A Y Combinator founder can use Stablecoin to raise funds. The money can then be deposited into a Stripe financial account to earn interest. When needed, the money can be directly used to pay the salaries of engineers worldwide—engineers who may be anywhere in the world. SaaS platforms can use smart contracts to collect stablecoin subscription fees, eliminating the need for wallet owners to manually sign every transaction. Companies using stablecoin for international expansion now have better payment tools, allowing them to directly embed digital wallets into their core products. With companies like Privy, Ramp, and Deel, businesses can manage both custodial and non-custodial wallets using a single API. Interoperability between stablecoin and fiat currencies is also rapidly improving. In April 2025, Bridge and Visa partnered to launch a card that allows businesses and consumers to spend their Stablecoins just like any other credit card. The card deducts money from the Stablecoin balance and automatically converts it to the local currency; merchants receive the payment indistinguishably from other payment methods, and may even be completely unaware that the user is paying with Stablecoins. Phantom, one of the most popular crypto wallets with 20 million monthly active users, is using Bridge to promote Stablecoin cards to its users. Even Visa has started issuing cards for Stablecoins. This means that the USDT in your wallet can already be used to buy a Coke at the convenience store on the corner. For payments, Stripe built a blockchain. Since it's preparing for the era of large-scale payments using stablecoins, Stripe has spent considerable time researching blockchain technology. Current blockchains are designed for transactions and DeFi; throughput, reliability, cost predictability, and privacy required for payments are not yet key considerations. Bitcoin can only process fewer than 10 transactions per second. In 2025, a surge in Meme coin trading on a major blockchain caused a Bridge user's payment to be delayed by more than 12 hours, and transaction fees for a single transaction skyrocketed by 35 times. These problems are critical, but the future will be even more critical. Because it is anticipated that most internet transactions in the future will be completed by intelligent agents, we need a blockchain capable of supporting more than one million, or even one billion transactions per second. In September 2025, Stripe and Paradigm jointly incubated Tempo, a blockchain specifically designed for payments. Tempo's logic is simple: I won't play those fancy DeFi games; I'll focus solely on payments. Dedicated payment channels: Not competing with Meme Coin. Sub-second final confirmation: As fast as swiping a credit card. Optional Privacy: Protects trade secrets while ensuring compliance. Interoperability with Compliance and Accounting Systems: Don't talk to me about money laundering; I know more about anti-money laundering than you do. These features may not seem significant, but they are crucial for the payment infrastructure that supports real economic activities. Visa, Nubank, and Shopify are already testing Tempo in various scenarios, including global payments, embedded finance, and remittances. Klarna, whose CEO once called himself a cryptocurrency skeptic, has now become the first bank to issue a stablecoin: KlarnaUSD on Tempo's testnet, using Bridge's Open Issuance to accelerate and reduce settlement costs for cross-border payments. Tempo's architecture is particularly well-suited for agent payments and microtransactions. The mainnet is launching soon; we look forward to seeing what new applications ambitious companies will develop with it. Small Business Financing Dilemma

Japan's aging population, Brexit, Europe's energy structure......

However, there is ample evidence that a significant culprit is the sharp decline in global capital availability.

In most OECD countries, bank capital requirements increased after the financial crisis, and capital availability for small businesses decreased.

Basel III reforms raised the capital standards for large global banks. In Ireland, bank lending to small businesses declined by more than 66% between 2011 and 2019. In the UK, small business lending has remained weak since contraction in 2012. The US fared slightly better, with non-bank lending institutions providing some access, and per capita GDP growth of 1.7% over the past 15 years. However, the overall trend in the post-Dodd-Frank era remains the same: tightening banking regulations and declining capital availability for small businesses. Since 2010, loans over $1 million have increased by 68%, while loans under $1 million have decreased by 5%. Last year, the approval rate for small business loans in the United States was only 41%, compared to 50% in 2015. Stripe Capital aims to address the global shortage of capital, particularly for small businesses. For businesses using Stripe for payments, their real-time revenue data simplifies loan decisions. Businesses can repay loans with a small percentage of subsequent sales, essentially drawing working capital from their own growth. From 2024 to 2025, funding increased by 45%, and Stripe Capital served over 80,000 companies. Many of these companies received funding through the vertical SaaS platforms they used—GlossGenius for beauty salons, Tekmetric for auto repair shops, Pixieset for photographers, and so on. Over the past two years, Stripe conducted a randomized study to understand the impact of capital: how fast can companies go when we "lubricate their wheels"? The result was, much faster. Companies that secured capital funding grew 27 percentage points faster than their peers who didn't receive funding in the following year. The top 10% of companies grew three times faster than their peers. The next tier also grew nearly 100 percentage points faster. For example, Xirsys, a California-based server hosting company, used funding from Stripe Capital to expand its server presence in China, India, and Japan, subsequently doubling its revenue. It's worth noting that even companies with low credit scores experienced 11 to 18 percentage points faster growth after securing funding. Stripe, in its letter, proposed a hypothesis: as AI improves ROI, capital availability may become a more significant variable in future economic outcomes. "Low-Income Model" OR "High-Income Model" For established companies, the number of clearly identifiable growth levers is pitifully small, and the most enticing ones don't necessarily work. Take advertising, for example. In 2019, Gillette's ad "The Best Men Can Be" won a Silver Lion at Cannes. Later that year, Procter & Gamble recorded an $8 billion impairment charge on this business because the award-winning ad failed to drive explosive growth. Recently, an Indian Railways advertisement won the Grand Prix and six Golden Lions at Cannes 2025—a daily lottery with a chance to win 10,000 rupees with a train ticket every day—but it was discontinued after eight weeks because no growth in ticket sales was seen. This is why Stripe, after 15 years, maintains a missionary-like passion for payments. Compared to more uncertain growth paths, optimizing payment settings is almost a guaranteed way to increase revenue, and one of the growth activities with the highest ROI. Microsoft evaluates the performance of each payment service provider monthly. From June to October 2025, Stripe significantly improved Microsoft's authorization rate using a series of methods, including adaptive acceptance, card account updaters, and network tokens. As a result, Microsoft shifted more payment traffic to Stripe. Gatwick Airport's previous payment provider had issues with payment failures, disputes, and customer complaints. After switching to Stripe, the payment success rate increased by 2.5 percentage points. FICO conducted an A/B test, comparing the previous payment provider with Stripe, and then completely switched, resulting in a 1 percentage point increase in the authorization rate. Telehealth's Royce saw a 2% increase in authorization rates and a 3% decrease in dispute rates over the past 12 months using Stripe, resulting in tens of millions of dollars in additional revenue annually. Most businesses are currently living in what Stripe calls the "low-revenue model": their payment infrastructure isn't optimized, and they're wasting money on conversion rates, authorization rates, and fraud prevention. What does the "high-revenue model" look like? The checkout page should be dynamically adjusted based on each customer. It should be priced in local currency and offer only the most relevant of hundreds of local payment options. Introducing BLIK payment to Polish customers increased checkout conversion rates by an average of 46%; offering Pix to Brazilian customers increased conversion rates by an average of 31%. Behind these achievements lies Stripe's decade-long investment in AI, including their "payment foundation model" and a suite of AI-driven services—Stripe Radar, Optimized Checkout Suite, and Authorization Boost—quietly optimizing billions of dollars in transactions daily. But there's still plenty of room for improvement! Last year, Stripe began testing a new authentication method: allowing customers to tap their cards to their phones. This touch verification validates the card's NFC chip, effectively proving that the cardholder possesses the card. DoorDash participated in the testing and found that compared to previous anti-fraud methods, conversion rates were significantly improved, and chargeback rates were reduced. Stripe also built a new model for Radar to address new fraud methods arising from the AI ​​wave—especially those that steal AI inference computing power through abuse of free trials, which are now very common. Here's an excerpt from the original text: CEOs: Flashy ads are fun, but don't overlook the growth opportunities right under your noses. Your heads of payments absolutely deserve more recognition. How about we hold an awards ceremony for them? In the south of France, to recognize payment optimization. Or if you think the weather there is too nice, San Francisco is also an option; April is perfect. The recent hot topic in the AI ​​world is that models can not only think using training data, but also go online, use browsers, write code, and do things on the internet. For Stripe's world, the most relevant concept is: your AI will soon be buying things for you. Like other AI concepts, agent-based commerce has also been overhyped prematurely. Some people make grand promises, claiming that autonomous agents will know your every preference and plan and execute all your shopping. Stripe breaks this promise down into five levels: Level 1: Eliminating Web Forms You research and decide what to buy yourself. But nobody likes filling out web forms. If you could directly send the agent a link, have them fill in payment and shipping information, and then confirm it with you, that would be much simpler. The system doesn't make any decisions; it just types and clicks "buy" for you. Level 2: Descriptive Search You no longer need to search for products or specific attributes, but rather describe the scenario. "I need to prepare back-to-school supplies for a third-grade child in Chicago, including clothes (not too tight or itchy!), pencils, notebooks, and a lunchbox. My son likes K-pop Demon Hunters and tennis. School starts at the end of August." The system considers weather, material, size, durability, taste, reviews, and delivery time. Niche and long-tail products become easier to find. Annoying keyword searches will become a thing of the past. Level 3: Long-lasting Memory You no longer need to introduce yourself. "Find me Bobby's back-to-school outfit options." The system already knows your preferences and remembers the requirements deduced from previous conversations and purchases. You still decide what to buy, but the options have been filtered based on your taste and budget. Level 4: Delegation You no longer need to make choices. "Get back-to-school shopping under $400." The system handles the searching, evaluating, and purchasing for you. You trust it to weigh the trade-offs and choose what your son likes, just like you do. You only set the budget. This is essentially what most people think about when they talk about agency-based business. Level 5: Proactive Prediction There aren't even any prompts. The system already knows the school calendar, your son's preferences, and your usual budget. You only receive one notification: Here's the list of school supplies already purchased. This is the most futuristic version: what you need appears just before you need it, without you even having to say a word. This industry is currently on the edge of Level 1 and Level 2. Stripe revisited the mid-1990s, the period when the internet architecture we use today was finalized. Netscape created the graphical browser. HTTP and HTML became the shared application layer. URLs and DNS took off. Back then, nobody knew which protocol or player would win. Every Google had an AltaVista in front of it. Now, proxy commerce is at a similar critical juncture—it has the potential to be a generational game-changer. Like the early internet, the future of proxy commerce depends on universal interoperability. To this end, Stripe did a lot last year: It collaborated with OpenAI on the Agentic Commerce Protocol (ACP), establishing a shared technical language between AI platforms and enterprises. Its open design allows it to be used across payment providers and AI platforms. It also launched Shared Payment Tokens, a new payment primitive that allows agents to initiate payments without exposing credentials. Even businesses that don't use Stripe for payment processing can forward these tokens to their own vaults or other processors as security credentials. The Agentic Commerce Suite has been released, providing businesses with a single tool that allows them to sell across multiple AI interfaces and protocols (including ACP and Google's Universal Commerce Protocol released last month) with a single integration. Checkout, payment, and fraud prevention all function normally at the underlying level. Brands already integrated include Anthropologie, Urban Outfitters, Etsy, Coach, and Kate Spade. Machine payments have also been launched, allowing developers to directly receive payments from agents using stablecoin micropayments—via API calls, MCP usage, and HTTP requests. Autonomous agents themselves are becoming a new customer type for internet companies. In collaboration with OpenAI, we've created the first shopping experiences on ChatGPT. We're also working with Microsoft to bring similar capabilities to Copilot. No one can accurately predict where agent-based business will be by the end of 2026, but it's clearly past the hype phase and entered the construction and real-world testing stage. The pace of change will only accelerate. If all goes well, those small agents won't be trapped in walled gardens, but will be racing along the wide highway of open protocols. The Republic of Licensing and the Cost of Innovation Today's entrepreneurs and innovators possess tools and reach unimaginable to previous generations of industrialists. How wonderful it would be if the combined effects of human ingenuity ultimately translated into increased productivity and improved living standards. Last year, Joel Mokyr won the Nobel Prize in Economics. Mokyr is known for emphasizing the importance of culture relative to traditional economic factors such as capital, labor, and technology. Eighteenth-century industrialists relied on more than just coal or geographical location. They possessed a new culture—a "reform mentality"—that viewed the status quo as imperfect and subject to correction. In *The Political Economy of Technological Change*, Mokyr also observes that new technologies have often failed in the past, not because they were not advanced enough, but because technology decisions involve not only suppliers and customers, but also a host of non-market aggregators—regulators, committees, courts—who influence what is adopted. As AI and the internet expand the boundaries of possibility, the synthetic barriers that hinder adoption and adaptation will become increasingly expensive. The economic divergence we are experiencing suggests that growth depends on the application of useful knowledge, not the existence of abstract knowledge itself. AI promises to greatly improve drug discovery… but this potential will only be realized if it makes regulatory processes (including clinical trials) faster and cheaper. European entrepreneurs can use new tools to revive a sluggish economy… but only if they cut back on well-intentioned but ultimately harmful burdens, such as the EU AI Act. Next-generation nuclear energy technology could bring energy abundance… but only if outdated regulatory systems are thoroughly reformed. Autonomous logistics—from long-haul trucks to drones—could drastically reduce the cost of physical goods… provided local regulations don't harden into barriers. Mokyr has written about the importance of “civilian republics” in catalyzing the Industrial Revolution. Today, we live in a “licensing republic”: a filter composed of non-market aggregators. While much regulation is well-intentioned, it is now more important than ever to ensure that it carefully weighs the benefits gained against the potential for being blocked. Fortunately, we can support resilient companies that demonstrate the boundaries of possibility: Mistral AI and Bending Spoons are proving that top European talent can pierce the regulatory freeze. Zipline and Varda are gradually securing licenses for complex new hardware. Spring Health and Maven Clinic are weaving new software layers for modern healthcare. We remain convinced that ideas are crucial to driving economic progress, and that many of the best ideas are undervalued. Stripe Press's book list contains many people, stories, and models that we believe can contribute to the next wave of improvement. The team recently celebrated selling one million books. Works in Progress, our magazine about undervalued, world-changing ideas, has also recently gone into print. The Event Horizon of a Black Hole This letter devotes a large portion to the progress of AI, sometimes making it feel like we're falling behind. The gap between newly released products and last year's most advanced technology is stark. We're reminded of the phenomenon of falling into a supermassive black hole. If you unfortunately experience this, the moment you cross the event horizon doesn't actually feel anything special: the path is locally smooth, although the space of future possibilities has irreversibly changed after crossing that boundary. As we write this letter, we may be standing on the eve of a different, hopefully better, singularity. While many things around us feel similar to previous years in 2026, it's also clear that the next decade will be completely different from the past one. We remain convinced that a vibrant entrepreneurial spirit and a wise culture will help build a more successful future society. We hope Stripe can play a small role. If you are also driving economic growth—whether as an entrepreneur, business leader, or builder of financial infrastructure—we hope to see you at Stripe Sessions in April. As always, there's much to discuss. That machine won't stop; it will only spin faster and faster. Whether you become the selected winner or just redundant data thrown out depends on how you deal with it now. That's all for now, see you next time.

data.title: Bit deer live by following water and grass
data.description:
Author: Zhou, ChainCatcher

Bitdeer's Bitcoin holdings have gone to zero.

As one of the leading mining companies, it held over 2400 BTC at its peak in November last year, then continuously increased its selling pace until it completed its liquidation in mid-February, and now it maintains a pace of selling as much as it mines.

... It's worth noting that the company's financial report shows that in the fourth quarter of 2025, it achieved revenue of US$224.8 million, a year-on-year increase of 226%; net profit reached US$70.5 million; total hashrate reached 71.0 EH/s, a year-on-year increase of 229%, and mining machine efficiency also increased significantly from 30.4 J/TH to 17.9 J/TH. A company with a blazing profit and record-high hashrate has chosen to clear its Bitcoin reserves at this time. To understand this operation, we need to return to a fundamental fact that has long been obscured by the market. 1. Coin hoarding has always been a minority strategy. BitDeer was never a faith-driven coin hoarding institution. In its early years, the company followed the simplest mining company logic—mine, sell, and convert to cash. BTC was not an asset to it, but a product. Until the last two years, when MicroStrategy's coin hoarding model gained immense popularity in the capital market, and the valuation logic of mining companies began to be reshaped, BitDeer followed the industry trend and briefly switched to a coin hoarding narrative. This kind of following the trend is not uncommon in the industry, but very few actually stick to it. Tom Dunleavy, an analyst at blockchain research firm Messari, released data showing that from January to November 2025, 10 major listed mining companies, including Core Scientific, Riot, Marathon, and Hut8, mined a total of approximately 40,700 BTC, while selling approximately 40,300 BTC during the same period, a sales rate of nearly 99%. In other words, these companies have never truly been hoarding coins. This figure reveals the industry's fundamental survival rule: mining companies are essentially energy arbitrageurs; Bitcoin is an intermediary for them to convert cheap electricity into revenue, not a long-term holding on their balance sheets. For some time, the market believed the hoarding story partly because the continuous rise in BTC prices masked this reality—when assets appreciate, selling becomes a matter of posture; but when prices fall below mining costs, selling transforms from a posture into a survival instinct. Therefore, BitDeer's recent liquidation is less a betrayal of faith and more a return to its true nature. It's certainly not a signal of a bearish outlook on Bitcoin; Wu Jihan himself stated on social media that holding zero positions doesn't mean it will always be that way. However, this time, the sale wasn't for operating cash, but for initial funding for a transformation. That brief period of hoarding was merely an interlude in the industry's collective narrative in cooperation with the capital market. 2. Triple Pressure: How Cold is the Winter for Mining Companies? Understanding that hoarding is a minority allows for a clearer view of the current situation of mining companies. And what weighs heavily on this industry is the predicament of three simultaneous tightening measures. First, there's the cost pressure after the halving. The 2024 halving means a reduction in block rewards, directly halving the output per unit for mining companies, while electricity costs, machine depreciation, and maintenance costs remain unchanged. The shutdown price of many mining machines is already close to or even exceeds the current BTC price, meaning that starting up results in losses, while shutting down wastes assets. Dunleavy also points out that miners' continuous selling of newly mined BTC itself constitutes structural downward pressure on prices. The lower the price, the more coins mining companies need to sell; the more coins sold, the harder it is for prices to rebound, thus creating a self-reinforcing vicious cycle. Secondly, there are the stark figures in the financial reports. Looking at the 2025 annual reports of mining companies, almost without exception, they all showed a structure where revenue increased, but so did losses. MARA Holdings' annual revenue increased from $656 million to $907 million, but its net loss reached a staggering $1.31 billion, compared to a profit of $541 million in the same period of the previous year. Hut 8's revenue increased from $162 million to $235 million, but its net loss changed from a profit of $331 million to a loss of $248 million. TeraWulf's full-year revenue increased from $140 million to $169 million, while its fourth-quarter loss per share widened from $0.21 to $1.66. The phenomenon of increased revenue but decreased profit is occurring simultaneously in several leading companies, indicating that this is not a management issue, but rather a structural cyclical contraction within the industry. Fluctuations in the fair value of cryptocurrency assets directly impact the profit and loss statement, making the figures on the books look particularly bad. Meanwhile, companies are still using debt to facilitate transformation: Hut launched a $1 billion ATM financing plan and signed a credit agreement with Coinbase for up to $400 million; Cipher Digital completed three financing rounds totaling $3.73 billion. Finally, the macroeconomic environment has changed. Trump's increase in global tariffs and the continued escalation of geopolitical uncertainty have put pressure on risk assets, with Bitcoin falling below $65,000. Cryptocurrency analysis firm QCP points out that Bitcoin's price is significantly lower than the average mining cost, and prioritizing liquidity over hoarding is no longer a strategic choice but a practical constraint. Bitdeer's liquidation and Cango's sale of small amounts of BTC for operational purposes, combined, outline the industry's trend towards risk-averse strategies. 3. A Gamble of Transformation: Facing Death to Survive Under the pressure of triple tightening, mining companies have only one way out: transformation, using the infrastructure assets accumulated through Bitcoin mining to unlock a new source of revenue. AI and high-performance computing have become the next card the industry collectively bets on. The logic is not difficult to understand. Mining companies hold a large number of cheap electricity contracts and scalable data center land, which are precisely the scarcest resources for AI computing infrastructure. Switching from low-margin mining power to high-margin AI computing power leasing seems like a profitable deal on paper. Bitdeer is aggressively developing its self-developed mining machines (Sealminer), AI cloud services, and high-performance computing businesses; Cipher has changed its brand from Mining to Digital, signaling its platform transformation; and several companies are vying to secure long-term, low-priced electricity contracts to build a structural moat in energy costs. However, the actual progress is far more conservative than the narrative suggests. Take TeraWulf as an example. In the fourth quarter, the company's revenue from HPC was only $9.7 million, accounting for less than 30% of its total revenue of $35.8 million, and a significant drop compared to the third quarter. Customer acquisition, contract signing, and capacity ramp-up for AI businesses all take time, while debt pressure and equity dilution are immediate. The outcome of this transformation gamble depends on whether the new business can truly scale up before the debt matures. Intriguingly, during the same period when BTC fell by nearly 17% in a single month, the stocks of several mining companies bucked the trend and strengthened. For example, TeraWulf rose 31% cumulatively this month, Cipher rose 8%, Hut 8 rose 6%, and Core Scientific remained basically flat. This decoupling reflects a revaluation in the capital market—mining companies have long been one of the sectors with the highest short positions held by hedge funds, and the upward momentum may partly come from short covering. This indicates that the market is beginning to see these companies as potential carriers of AI computing power infrastructure, rather than leverage amplifiers for Bitcoin prices. In the future, their evaluation criteria may no longer be who holds how much BTC, but who has locked in the longest-term low-priced electricity, whose data center assets have the greatest potential for AI transformation, and whose balance sheet can weather the pain of transformation. Conclusion Mining companies have never been the most devout believers in Bitcoin; they are the most rational industry participants. When mining is profitable, they mine; when hoarding coins can support valuations, they choose to hoard coins; when selling coins can provide the funds for transformation, they will sell without hesitation. This is the basic logic of business. The real question worth pursuing is the next one: after the AI/HPC transformation story has been fully priced in by the capital market, what will these companies have left to support the next round of valuations? If the price of Bitcoin has recovered by then, and the transformation business is not yet mature, will those mining companies that are clearing out their positions today start telling the story of hoarding coins again? Cycles come and go, narratives are ever-evolving. But in every current winter, survival is always more important than faith.
